knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)

```{r}
#library needed
library("tidyverse")
library("ggplot2")
library("leaflet")
library("data.table")
```

## 1. Read in the data

```{r read-data, cache=TRUE}
if (!file.exists("met_all.gz"))
  download.file(
    url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/USCbiostats/data-science-data/master/02_met/met_all.gz",
    destfile = "met_all.gz",
    method   = "libcurl",
    timeout  = 60
    )
met <- data.table::fread("met_all.gz")
```

## 2. Prepare the data

```{r create-ymd, cache=TRUE}
#Remove temperatures less than -17C
head(met)
met <- met[met$temp >= -17]

#Make sure there are no missing data in the key variables coded as 9999, 999, etc
summary(met)
#we can see the maximum value fo elev is 9999.0
met <- met[elev == 9999.0, elev := NA]
summary(met)

#Generate a date variable using the functions as.Date()
met[, ymd := as.Date(paste(year, month, day, sep = "-"))]

#Using the data.table::week function, keep the observations of the first week of the month.
met[, table(week(ymd))]
met <- met[ week(ymd) == 31]
```





```{r}
#Compute the mean by station of the variables temp, rh, wind.sp, vis.dist, dew.point, lat, lon, and elev.


met_avg <- met[, .(
  temp = mean(temp, na.rm = T),
  rh = mean(rh, na.rm = T),
  wind.sp = mean(wind.sp, na.rm = T),
  vis.dist = mean(vis.dist, na.rm = T),
  dew.point = mean(dew.point, na.rm = T),
  lat = mean(lat, na.rm = T),
  lon = mean(lon, na.rm = T),
  elev = mean(elev, na.rm = T)
), by = "USAFID"]

met_avg
```
```{r}
#Create a region variable for NW, SW, NE, SE based on lon = -98.00 and lat = 39.71 degrees
met_avg[, region := fifelse(lon >= -98 & lat > 39.71, "NE",
                    fifelse(lon < -98 & lat > 39.71, "NW",
                    fifelse(lon < -98 & lat <= 39.71, "SW", "SE"
                    )))]
table(met_avg$region)
```

```{r}
#Create a categorical variable for elevation as in the lecture slides
met_avg[, elev_cat := fifelse(elev > 252, "high", "low")]
table(met_avg$elev_cat)
```

## 3. Use geom_violin to examine the wind speed and dew point temperature by region


```{r violin}
#wind speed
met_avg[!is.na(elev_cat) & !is.na(region)] %>%  # deal with NA category
ggplot(met_avg, mapping = aes(y = wind.sp, x = 1, color = region, fill = region)) +
  geom_violin() +
  facet_grid(~region)
#dew point
met_avg[!is.na(elev_cat) & !is.na(region)] %>% 
ggplot(met_avg, mapping = aes(y = dew.point, x = 1, color = region, fill = region)) +
  geom_violin() 
```
**The highest dew point is in Southest region. The southwest have the highest wind speed.**

## 4. Use geom_jitter with geom_smooth to examine the association between dew point temperature and wind speed by region

```{r geom_jitter_and_geom_smooth}
met_avg[!is.na(region) & !is.na(wind.sp) & !is.na(dew.point)] %>%
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = wind.sp, y = dew.point)) +
  geom_point(mapping = aes(color = region)) +
  geom_smooth(formula = y ~x, method = lm, mapping = aes(linetype = region))+
  facet_wrap(~ region, nrow = 2)
```
**Southwest region is only one have a negative association between wind speed and dew point.**

## 5. Use geom_bar to create barplots of the weather stations by elevation category coloured by region

```{r geom_bar}
met_avg[!is.na(elev_cat)] %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x = elev_cat, fill = region), position = "dodge") +
  labs(x = "Elevation Categories" , y = "Frequency", title = "Elevation by Region") +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Spectral")
```
**Most of stations in nouthest region have low elevation.**


## 6. Use stat_summary to examine mean dew point and wind speed by region with standard deviation error bars

```{r stat_summary}
ggplot(
  met_avg[!is.na(wind.sp) & !is.na(region)],
  mapping = aes(x=region, y = wind.sp)) +
  stat_summary(fun.data="mean_sdl") +
  stat_summary(fun.data="mean_sdl", geom="errorbar")

ggplot(
  met_avg[!is.na(dew.point) & !is.na(region)],
  mapping = aes(x=region, y = dew.point)) +
  stat_summary(fun.data="mean_sdl") +
  stat_summary(fun.data="mean_sdl", geom="errorbar")
```
**Southwest region have the strongest wind speed. Southest have highest dew point.**

## 7. Make a map showing the spatial trend in relative h in the US

```{r}
# Make a colour palette with custom colours
rh.pal <- colorNumeric(c('darkgreen','goldenrod','brown'), domain=met_avg$rh)
rh.pal

#Use addMarkers to include the top 10 places in relative h (hint: this will be useful rank(-rh) <= 10)
top10rh <- met_avg[ rank(-rh) <= 10]

rhmap <- leaflet(top10rh) %>% 
  # The looks of the Map
  addProviderTiles('CartoDB.Positron') %>% 
  # Some circles
  addCircles(
    lat = ~lat, lng=~lon,
                                                  # HERE IS OUR PAL!
    label = ~paste0(rh), color = ~ rh.pal(rh),
    opacity = 1, fillOpacity = 1, radius = 500
    ) %>%
  # And a pretty legend
  addLegend('bottomleft', pal=rh.pal, values=met_avg$rh,
          title='Relative Humid.', opacity=1)
rhmap


```

**As we can see, top 10 stations with highest rh distributed at coast and midland of US.**
